Designing Your Open Digital Badge Ecosystem.

Digital Badges Bibliography by HASTAC.

Open Badges for Lifelong Learning by Mozilla Foundation and Peer 2 Peer University in collaboration with the MacArthur Foundation.

7 Things You Should Know About Badges.

Badges

A badge is a symbol or indicator of an accomplishment, skill, competency or interest. Badges provide evidence of learning that happens in and beyond the classroom. Badges give prospective employers, professional groups, community groups, schools, collaborators and other learners a more complete picture of knowledge, skills, and abilities. Badges are certified by a learning provider - either formal or informal - and digital badges contain the certifying metadata which validates the accomplishment.

Mozilla has created a platform to help badge users and issuers track their badges. OpenBadges is free software developed on an open technical standard that anyone can use to create, issue and verify badges. It also offers badge earners a 'badge backpack' in which to aggregate their badges to share with educators or employers.

title: Mobile Learning
body:
Mobile Learning

A May 2013 study by the Pew Internet & American Life Project found that 34 percent of cell internet users go online mostly using their mobile devices. For higher education, this implies that it is becoming ever more important that our course offerings and materials be accessible by mobile device. Mobile learning offers institutions the ability to deliver education in the just-in-time manner in which students use their mobile devices.

Outsourcing - Creating Great Partnerships

Game Changers by Diana Oblinger

Third-party Providers

e-Learning administrators work with all kinds of third-party vendors. For distance education, there are learning management systems and course design and development. An increasing number of institutions develop contracts with third-party providers for their services. However, ultimately, it is the institution's responsibility to be accountable to accreditors, students, faculty, and to the institution's overall reputation and brand. It is essential that institutional providers of online and distance education develop strong relationships and partnerships with any third-party providers.

title: State and Federal Regulations on State Authorization of Distance Education
body:
State Authorization of Out-of-State Institutions

Whether via distance education, practical experiences, or face-to-face, states expect that institutions obtain approval before enrolling students, advertising, marketing, or performing other regulated activities in their state. The requirements as to which activities require authorization, the application processes, and the costs to comply vary greatly from state-to-state.

In 2010, the U.S. Department of Education issued a regulation tying an institution's ability to offer federal financial aid in a state to the institution being authorized in the student's state. The regulation was subsequently "vacated" by federal court ruling and is not currently being enforced. The Department is currently in the process of reinstating the regulation. Regardless of the status of the federal regulation, states still expect institutions to follow their laws and regulations.

  • History of State Authorization
  • State Approval Requirements
  • Getting Started with State Approval
  • Sample Letters, Complain Processes, and Webpages
  • Student Complaints
  • Reciprocal Agreements

Programmatic, Systematic, Automatic: An Online Course Accessibility Support Model

Accessibility

At its root, accessibility is about providing all students, online or on-ground, with equal opportunity to learn. For online and technology-enhanced higher education, extra steps must be taken to ensure that course materials, social media and other interactive tools have been designed in a manner that allows all students to utilize them. Several laws are in place to ensure that students are able to gain the access they need to educational materials. The resources provided here will help you and your institution set your students up for success by providing learning materials in formats that are accessible.

Guidelines for the Review and Evaluation of Distance Education

Trusted Seal of Integrity

Academic Integrity

Academic integrity is a complex issue and yet a critical one for institutions to address. Since the HEOA of 2008, academic integrity now is entwined with the federal requirement that accreditors ensure programs have processes to verify student identity. WCET has led a number of important efforts to clarify, inform, educate, and lead good practices for academic integrity. WCET's Academic Integrity and Student Authentication Common Interest Group (CIG) continues its work to identify and disseminate information on promising practices to promote integrity of which identity authentication is but one component.

WCET's CIG on Academic Integrity

The Case for Competency Based Education: A New Age of Teaching and Learning?

Competency-based Education

Competency-based education is an educational delivery model which assesses a students mastery of pre-defined competencies for advancement toward a credential. Competency-based education uses learning instead of time as the measure of student success. Inherent to this model's use of defined learning outcomes, CBE leads to greater transparency and accountability to students and stakeholders. While many are still debating the definition of 'competency,' programs are growing rapidly to help meet national completion goals.

Many competency-based education programs appeal to the many students with some credits but no degree. Competency-based programs offer the flexibility, defined outcomes which increase employability, and acceptance of prior learning that make them attractive to this burgeoning demographic.

Predictive Analytics: Reading Resources

Learning Analytics

Data driven decision making is part of the business intelligence methodologies framework that has transformed such diverse industries as online marketing, ecommerce, digital self-service and online dating. As a derivative of these business intelligence methodologies, learning analytics help inform institutional decision making utilizing data institutions already collect. This can focus energy and resources at points of demonstrated need to support student success through improved retention and progress toward completion of certificates and degrees.

Prior Learning Assessment

Prior Learning Assessment (PLA) is used to describe the process of evaluating learning gained outside the college classroom. PLA has been an option for college students, especially returning adult learners and military personnel, to advance their degree-seeking goals. PLA has gained greater prominence recently as one key component in examining all alternative pathways to credentials. The three common methods of assessing prior learning include examinations, review of training, and portfolio assessment.

title: Student Authentication
body:
Recent News on
Student Authentication

  • Cheating, Student Authentication and Proctoring in Online Programs
  • something went wrong

Events

WCET 2013 Annual Meeting:
Let's Map! Academic Integrity Clarifications. See the session summary.

WCET 2012 Annual Meeting:
Student Fraud: A Problem You Can't Ignore

Resources

Consortium of College Testing Centers of the National College Testing Association

Student Authentication

Student authentication in distance education has been an issue of interest to federal policy makers for several years. The growth in enrollments and in the number of educational providers of online learning fueled concerns about the ability of institutions to verify the identity of online students throughout the cycle of an online course: registration, participation, assessment, academic credit. Passage of the Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2008, followed by federal rule making, resulted in new regulations. One regulation required accrediting agencies to assure distance and correspondence education programs have processes in place to verify student identity. WCET has led a number of important efforts aimed at informing policy makers, accrediting agency leaders, and online program administrators of different approaches - pedagogical as well as technological - that ensure their compliance with the regulation but also raise the conversation to a more widely relevant discussion of academic integrity.
